thread.title: Chesapeake Bay truck driver blown off bridge and dies
thread.title_full: Chesapeake Bay truck driver blown off bridge and dies | Daily Mail Online

author: Keith Griffith For Dailymail.com
title: Chesapeake Bay truck driver blown off bridge and dies
text:
A truck driver is dead in a freak accident on the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel, after high winds blew his truck off the bridge. 
The unlucky man was driving southbound on the 23-mile bridge and tunnel complex linking the Delmarva Peninsula with Virginia Beach when the horror wreck occurred at around 12.30pm. 
Gusts of wind up to 40mph are believed to have knocked the white tractor-trailer out of its lane and through the steel railing on the bridge, a bridge official told 13News . 
The truck plunged over the edge of the bridge into the wind-whipped whitecaps of the 45-degree water below. 
Scroll down for video 
Vehicles sits on the road by a missing section of guard rail along a segment of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge-Tunnel where a tractor-trailer went over the southbound side at the 15-mile marker
A truck driver died after heavy winds swept his tractor trailer off the 23-mile bridge-tunnel between Virginia Beach and the Delmarva Peninsula
Traffic halted as onlookers rushed to spot the driver and call for help. 
Authorities say that the driver was spotted alive on top of the cab's truck minutes later, where he waited desperately for help. 
Navy fliers with the Helicopter Sea Combat Squadron 2, based out of nearby Naval Station Norfolk, happened to be on hand in a MH-60 S Sikorsky Knight Hawk. 
'They were on a routine training flight and saw the wreck,' Naval Air Force Atlantic spokesman Mike Maus told the Virginian-Pilot . 
As the truck sank cab-first beneath the wind-tossed sea, the Navy helicopter crew descended to rescue the driver at around 2.00pm, successfully managing to get him into the craft. 
A Navy helicopter plucked a driver from the roof of the floating vehicle, but he later died, authorities said
The truck was still submerged late Thursday, having reportedly floated up to a mile away from the bridge
The hero crew raced toward Sentra General Hospital in Norfolk, but the driver died in the air before they could reach waiting doctors. 
Officials have not yet identified the driver of confirmed the cause of the accident. 
Traffic on the bridge was closed in both directions for about 2 hours, until reopening at 2.30pm. 
The truck was still submerged late Thursday, having reportedly floated up to a mile away from the bridge. 
Ten vehicles – seven trucks and three cars – went over the side of the bridge complex between 1964 and 2011, according to the Virginan-Pilot. Only one survived. 
Since then, one truck driver drowned after crashing into the water, and another went through the railing but survived the plunge.
